Germany has different problems. After WW2, Germany set up mechanisms to prevent authoritarian dictatorship. This also applies to education in schools.
China's government can simply cordon off an entire city if few illnesses occur. In Germany there is a discussion right away: who has the right to determine that?
About 75% + x of the population then follows the instructions. Social media and secret chat rooms make it easy to spread fake news. The Russian channel was only recently banned.

And then Germany also slept under 16 + 12 years of conservative government. A digital reform in the healthcare system was only decided shortly before the pandemic. This is not yet fully functional. That means the government has big problems getting up-to-date data. Responsibilities are disputed, bureaucracy causes a lot of friction.

On the other hand, at the end of last year, an expert on pandemics came to the head of the Ministry of Health.
Professor Doctor med. Karl Lauterbach. However, he now has to turn things around on the Titanic.
But 16 federal states have to cooperate. At least everyone is rowing in the same direction now, even if some complain about the direction from time to time.
A lot has to be changed politically, but there is no respite for that now.

Unfortunately the "news" and numbers you are relying on are propaganda so much of the work you've put into this is quite pointless. If you're interested as to the reasoning behind this I recommend continuing your fascination with epidemiology and virology. The crux of this pandemic is the PCR test. Assuming every "positive" is indicative that the individual is infected with Covid-19 at the moment of the test is where it falls apart. This is scientifically not a true statement and why this test has not been used to determine other viral infections in the past. Additionally, the more you test, the less accurate the results become. This is a major factor in why we tested more in America and saw a higher rate of "positive" cases.

So yes, good study but much, most of your data is not scientifically sound. This sounds like conspiracy theory because it is. The news and media are pushing a narrative to deceive us into accepting a viral pandemic in order to impose mandates, print trillions of dollars, and embrace a vaccine that has killed thousands. The truth becomes obvious when you look into it and see the massive effort to hide these points and much more.

You're a smart person and I hope you can see that a single story is being forced through main stream sources while a massive amount of contrary data is suppressed and deleted. Every effort has been made to convince you that Covid-19 is a very real viral pandemic killing millions on a global scale. The truth is the numbers are so erroneous and conflated that we will probably never know the real extent of the virus. What we do know is that based on the data; shut downs, distancing, and masks appear to have very little to no affect on viral transmission (again based on erroneous numbers). And that the virus is over 99% survivable - much more than dozens of other virus'. Again several sources are pointing this out yet I doubt you'll hear of it on CNN.

According to the official statistics, South Africa has turned into one of the greatest epicenters of Covid-19 in the world. Since the beginning of April to the 12th July, the cumulative number of infections in South Africa has doubled about every 14 days. On 12 July 2020, 264,184 cumulative cases have been recorded, slightly more than double the 131,800 on 28 June, 14 days before. South Africa was firmly on track to record half a million cumulative infections by 25 July. Community spread appeared unstoppable. At that rate of increase, 1 million would have been infected by 8 August, 2 million by 22 August, 4 million by 5 September, 8 million by 19 September, 16 million by 3 October and some 32 million by 17 October 2020. That would represent 53% of the population of over 59 million people. The daily number of new infections should then have dropped off steeply. On that trend, over the first two weeks of October, between one and two million new infections were likely to occur daily. The growth of new cases in adjoining areas, such as Zimbabwe, Namibia, Eswathini, Botswana and Lesotho was much, much slower.

However, on 13 July, the number of new cases in South Africa dropped significantly by about 1,440, or about 11%. The day before, the 12 July 2020, sales of alcoholic beverages were prohibited in South Africa, creating a false impression that the ban was the cause of the drop in numbers. However, this is false, because the normal lag period of some 5 to 10 days between the introduction of a new measure that is effective, and a reduction in case numbers, was completely absent, clearly identifying it as fake. This trend of a reduction of new cases continued daily and became progressively stronger. The result was that, today, 19 September, the official cumulative number of cases in South Africa stands at 657,627 instead of about 11.63 million, had the 'trend' of doubling every 13 or 14 days continued. There is no rational reason for a ban on liquor sales to cause such a sudden, steep drop in new cases. Hence the conclusion is that, over the three-and-a-half months before 12 July, the numbers have been manipulated up, as were the numbers on recoveries. Death numbers, on the other hand, were manipulated down: https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/national/2020-07-29-excess-deaths-soar-to-more-than-four-times-official-covid-19-toll-mrc-data-shows/.

The question is, why have the case numbers been manipulated up?

Early this year, South Africa applied for an IMF loan of US$4.3 billion at a very low interest rate. On 27 July, the IMF publicly announced that the loan was granted - https://www.imf.org/en/News/Articles/2020/07/27/pr20271-south-africa-imf-executive-board-approves-us-billion-emergency-support-covid-19-pandemic. Most likely, South Africa was informed of the grant earlier than the public announcement, perhaps around 12 July? Clearly, the numbers in South Africa have been manipulated up to impress on the IMF an urgent need for funds to fight the epidemic in the country. Most of the funds are likely to land in the pockets of corrupt people in positions of power and their family.

A further question is, what is the real motive for the ban on liquor sales?

The answer is that the ban on liquor sales will most likely drive many liquor stores out of business. The liquor trade is seen as lucrative, easy business. White owners of such businesses are exempt on a racist basis of financial assistance to weather the covid storm, including the IMF funds. I think one way the data should be represented is to show the number of confirmed cases relative to the number of tests being conducted. As mentioned in your video, the numbers reflected only show the number of tested positive cases, and the true number can never be known. Nevertheless, having the number of tests conducted relative to the number of tested positive cases can give us a good idea of the prevalence of the pandemic in that particular country. For instance if the "hit rate" of the positive cases relative to the number of tests is low, then we can infer (to a limited extent) that the actual numbers in that particular country is expected to be low. Conversely, if the number of positive cases are low, but the "hit rate" is high, then we know that insufficient testing is being done, and the actual numbers could in fact be much higher.
It will also be interesting to find out how many tests are being conducted on a per-capita basis (e.g. tests per million) so that we can know if a country is or isn't conducting enough tests, and whether or not more aid (global or otherwise) should be provided to those countries.

@minutephysics, I'm afraid you have a SERIOUS error here. What you are plotting is log(dy/dt) vs. log(y), so a straight line means log(dy/dt) = k*log(y), or dy/dt = y^k.
Thus, y = exp(integral of y^(k-1)*t). Since k < 1, this is an exponential only in form because as y grows the y^(k-1) term shrinks. If k = 0.5, then by the time there are a million cases, that term is 10^-5 of the value it started out with, assuming that k stayed constant.

I wonder how much skepticism re: China is based in anti-Chinese/anti-“communism” and how much is based in fact. There’s a few points here worth mentioning. First, we’re months into this and still don’t have adequate tests. So why should we conclude that the Chinese government is ‘hiding’ numbers when it can only be assumed that they too didn’t, and likely still don’t have testing available. Second, if the Chinese were hiding numbers, why would they have released numbers after changing the diagnostics that caused a one-day jump of over something like 14k cases? Third, China was extremely aggressive in both quarantine and treatment early on. They built massive hospitals to treat anyone with symptoms in dormatory-style settings - whereas americans claim a lack of hospital beds because we demand private rooms for every patient. I recently saw footage from a makeshift hospital in NYC where each space could easily house at least three patients. China was in a unique situation, politically as well as culturally to address the crisis in a way that could not be replicated elsewhere. There is literally no reason to suspect the Chinese numbers are misrepresented intentionally, aside from wild speculation driven by anti-Chinese sentiments rooted in cold-war era bias.

(d) is possibly interesting.

A hysteresis. Where a wave is propagating through a medium from a source of emission towards a detector (or observer), transmitting at the speed permitted by the medium and oscillating at the frequency determined by the emitter - if anything happens to the source of emission that effect changes in the way the wave is propagating, then until all of the remaining wave nodes that were still travelling towards the detector through the medium since before the change in the source of emission have been observed, you most likely will not immediately observe any change in the pattern of the propagating wave, until the nodes that reflect that change have reached the detector. Unless, maybe one is using non-linear and/or bilinear techniques as well as linear techniques lol, that is assuming we have even come that far yet 😏 also taking into account changes in the medium and the way it permits further transmission, and then if we consider non-local transmission, where information exchanges appear to take place at a speed not permitted by the medium and in an indeterminate order - pfft, nah! that's going a bit far lol. I think your Analysis is somewhat flawed based on the point that in most countries (well, mostly im speaking for the european ones) lowering the infection-rate is not the main goal(at the moment as we dont have potent visustatika yet so this is not achievable without a complete quarantine instead of a partial one which is currentliy not in place and which would have serious repercussions to the ability of the countries to keep neccessary services running). I am a Medicine Student myself in Germany and we fully expect the virus to have its projected High point of the Infection Rate in september. After this point the Infection Rate is expected to go down based on historic Data collected from earlier pandemics and Population studies, because many people will have developed asymptomatic (partial) immunity or had the symptoms alredy so the infection chain is interrupted. The main goal is to keep the Infection rate relatively low which on our Graph is correctly displayed as Growth, but without this Context it could be interpretet as Failure of containing this Health crisis. In reality the Quarantine is working better than you would read from the graph, because we are able to keep the infection rate low enough to not overencumber our intensive care Units for the seroius cases. So more important is the infected to dead and infected to recovered ratio imo.
Also a side note to the situation in China: They did many things right that many other countries failed to do like acting very quick and strict, but those numbers are always to be taken with caution referring to the last SARS corona situation and their information handling then. This is a great video...but it has 2 significant problems:

Item 1: The Y-axis should be logarithmic, yes. But it should also be logarithmic on # of cases PER CAPITA, not on # of cases. That way you'd be comparing policies and techniques on a 1-to-1 basis, comparing oranges-to-oranges, no matter the size of the country. Under the current scheme, little Lichtenstein will inevitably look like a hero; but not because their policies and techniques are the best!

Item 2: The stats from China are almost certainly falsified, as gobs of news stories are now reporting. It is, of course, true that China does things no free country would think to do; e.g., weld people into their homes, make medical care dependent on one's social credit score, etc. This allows draconian measures for epidemic control that the U.K. would (hopefully) never tolerate.

BUT, it is also true that the recent Chinese stats are impossible to take seriously. Merely comparing the mainland (where they can control and falsify information) to Hong Kong (where they can't) shows the disparity. If the stats from Wuhan are to be believed, one magical day a couple of weeks ago, they just stopped getting new cases, and the daily numbers since then have been a smooth, flat line (not the jagged bouncing line you get from real-world reporting with real delays).

And then there's the somewhat morbid observation: If the death rates have leveled off, why is it the crematoria still have an exponential increase in business, and a backlog? File that under "things that make you go 'Hmm.'"

The stats just don't pass the laugh test, and we should stop pretending that China is the exemplar in this pandemic.

Use South Korea instead, please. They're getting it right, their stats can be trusted, and their methods don't include welding people into houses.

China and South Korea tell a lot of lies - their figures just cannot be trusted.  The massive spike in fatalities we saw in Italy compared to China/Iran/Korea is because the Italians by and large tell the truth.

You made a fundamental mistake: The double log scale is used to show potential dependencies as a straight line (e.g. X squared). This is due to log(X**Y) = Y * log(X). So, if I plot log(X**Y) versus log(X) I get a straight line with slope Y.
What you need to do is to keep the linear scale for time and plot it versus a logarithmic scale for the number of cases.

Forget the infection data.  It is hopelessly flawed.  Instead, plot the log of reported COVID deaths against linear time.  After all, what matters here is how many will die, not how many will cough.  Then interpret the changes in the slope as a function of lockdown measures.  Use this to project the trajectory of what will happen in countries like the USA based on the data for countries which locked down earlier.  This avoids unrealistic assumptions about lockdown effectiveness, such as those being made by Trump's advisors.  The varying mortality rate also essentially factors out since you are only looking at how policy affects the total mortality over time.  Said another way, how much you slow it down is independent of what percentage of people die.  Also, imperfection in the deaths data is unimportant as we can imagine it's about the same for all countries.  Using this approach, you should be able to quickly show extrapolations for the USA based on them adopting various degrees of lockdown over time.  For that, one can assume that they will repeat the policy path of others, that is, starting with loose lockdown (current status) and thereafter tightening it at specific dates.  Make it simple and just show the set of curves for going from the current status to total lockdown (similar to Italy or France) at various dates.  You should be able to quickly show that the total deaths will far exceed the 240,000 the government is predicting, and under all circumstances.  These are the projections that Americans need to see.

Major caveat not mentioned: “confirmed case” doesn’t = bad case. Confirmed cases can also be asymptomatic cases, meaning the entire graph is nonsense in regards to policy and decision making. We don’t want confirmed cases to stop, we want everyone to be exposed and recover... all the graph shows is a fall-off in testing, not the spread. It makes sense that the people who are susceptible to this particular virus will fall seriously ill early on and then that number of people will abruptly decline because they’ve all been exposed and either died or recovered, NOT because a government hit a magical “eject button” and made up a policy. That’s “natural selection” in progress... a virus sweeps through a population, those who are susceptible get sick, those who aren’t continue unaffected... not because of a policy but because of biology. Nothing we’re doing is going to have any affect on the relationship between this virus and the human population. You can hide inside all you want, eventually everyone IS going to “get it” and the outcome will be the same. Not being heartless, just pointing out the obvious. If actual cases were on a graph it would be an exponential hockey stick all the way up to the total population #, then nothing. The graph is only plotting cases serious enough to warrant testing, not every possible carrier.
It’s a sensationalized doomsday graph. Reality says COVID 19 isn’t something to “beat”, it’s just another flu bug that will always be with us. Plotting only serious illness and deaths is great if your goal is to scare people. The vast majority of people will never even know they’ve been exposed, and probably already have been.

The data visualization needs a way to normalize the data to make the comparisons have some additional meaning, say plot new confirmed cases per thousand on one axis vs total confirmed cases per thousand on the other. If we do not do this with all other things being equal the smaller countries will tend to drop of the trajectory low on the graph while countries with larger populations will drop off the trajectory after climbing further. I'd be really interested to see data regarding the change in death rate in afflicted countries. Particularly the death rate from medical causes (ie, excluding accidents, suicide/homicide, etc).
As you, and many others, have stated: we simply have no idea how many actual cases of coronavirus there are, and how many deaths can actually be attributed to it. There's quite a bit of speculation that coronavirus was already present and causing hospitalization or death months ago. If that is the case, it's not only possible but I would say likely that this virus has already infected a large number of people, much larger than we think. But because we're only testing those who we have reason to test (the people showing the most severe symptoms) we have drastically skewed data that is making us think things are much worse than they actually are.
When a pandemic like the 1918 flu strikes, the death rate spikes dramatically. Obviously. The number of people that are dying that wouldn't normally die is being elevated. The number of people having heart attacks, strokes, etc should be fairly constant, so if we see random, otherwise unexplained spikes in the overall death rate, and at the same time there is a pandemic sweeping humanity, that gives us a bit clearer of a look at things. We may not be able to test everyone for coronavirus or accurately attribute coronavirus to deaths, but even the most inefficient backwoods systems can generally tell you how many people have died during a certain period of time. If this number is spiking for no otherwise apparent reason, probably coronavirus.
I suspect we will see a slight elevation in deaths over the past few months. Coronavirus was setting in before anyone really cared. And I think it did start infecting people at an exponential rate, and we did start to see an exponential rise in deaths, but most people are able to fight it off like a common cold so no one really cared that much. It probably meant that people at high risk, ie the very old, the already sickly, and the most immuno-compromised, saw the highest death rates. But old people dying, pardon the callousness.... is not really news. Something was going to kill them, it turns out an extremely infectious but otherwise relatively mild contagion will do the trick. Once we noticed the trend, the alarms started to sound off and we became immensely focused. Even though we're quite likely well past the peak of infection, we only now start testing, and so to us this infection is "starting" to spread exponentially.
The rise in coronavirus cases probably has far more to do with measuring our ability to test for a disease than it does the actual presence and/or threat the disease poses. In short, stop buying toilet paper and stop panicking. But do wash your hands. Pandemic or not, that's just basic hygiene, don't be gross.

A nice way to understand exponential growth is by it's derivative.
Let's suppose that transmission occurs only once in the day, like all potential transmissions are done at once, each day.
Derivative is the growth rate. As for example, a linear function has a constant derivative. That would be a case where each person can only transmit covid to one other person. Starting from one, each day there would be one more person. Growth rate is the difference of ill people between two days (here is one, all the time)
Covid is exponential growth, because each person can transmit it every day and is not limited to one person. But to make it simple, we will assume it can only transmit to one each day. So starting at one, second day two, third day four etc. The difference each day is the number of ill people the day before. That's exponential.
A really simple way to see if growth is exponential, plot total number of patients detected at each time (day), and daily patients detected. If both curves are more or less the same shape, that's exponential growth :)

My question is: how would the above graph look if instead of numbers of cases, the number of cases relative to the total population of a region were used as the dependent variable? In some small countries, 10k cases would be more than 1% of the entire population, whereas in the US, it would be around 0.003% of the total population. It seems to me that in a larger country, there would likely be several independent centers of contagion, each with its own start date and rate of growth, but the figures for that country would be their sum—would this distort the exponentiality of the growth curve? Also, the upper limit on growth would obviously be quite different in, say, Iceland versus the US.

There's one thing that's often forgotten.

It's that just because a country might have the situation under control now, doesn't mean that the virus won't come back. And that will be the problem. These measures are so strict, keeping the measures for many months, maybe several years, while hoping for a vaccine might be more damaging than the virus itself in the long run. Even though it looks like China is getting control, it doesn't mean a second, third, even forth wave won't come. So how long is China willing to keep their country shut down and keep entire provinces under constant curfews? Some say a vaccine might be two years away, other say it's possible that we might never find a vaccine.

So the second a country ease up their protective measures, the virus will come back. And you'll have the whole situation again.

And another thing often not talked about is the mutations this virus is doing. A week ago Iceland found 40 different mutations of the virus, in a relative small number of infected. Viruses like these are programmed to make mutations, in order to survive when people develop immunity. This is probably what happened with the Spanish flu, as most peolpe who died from the Spanish flu died about one year in, during two big waves. These new waves was most likely caused by mutations, making the virus more deadly. Then, out of no-where, all of a sudden - the deaths stopped. No-one at the time knew why, but now we understand it was probably because a new mutation of the virus was defeating the other mutation; and this new mutation just happened to not be as deadly.

So, we might have mutations making this virus far worse than it is now causing new waves, or we might also have new mutations making this virus less dangerous.

The projection graphs like these are showing, shows the current situation - but we know of experience with viruses that they come in waves. So seeing numbers go down might just be a false sense of security. We're just seeing the first wave go down, we don't know how many waves there's gonna be. There might just be one wave, or there might be five waves.

few caveats: the "true" exponential growth rate isn't necessarily below the rate of confirmed cases when accounting for the increase in testing. in most countries only people with symptoms are tested. they automatically become more and more numerous - and so do the tests. Tests do not capture "more" as long as the criteria of testing stay the same. the "true" growth rate can even be above the "apparent" rate. For example, at the beginning of spreading, transmission rate is higher among younger age cohorts (children, adolescents) because of more intense social interactions, but these young cohorts tend to have no symptoms and thus remain untested.

This is great, but I think it can be even better. By plotting number against number, you end up with a "main sequence" along the diagonal, creating what one colleague calls a "space plot" (lots of wasted space). Instead, plot the ratio of new cases to total cases (physically, this is something like a growth rate) on the horizontal axis. This emphasises small deviations from the main sequence. I plotted the NY Times' collection of data for US counties, and you can see the growth rate spike at 50% for some counties, before coming down to something more like 20% in the last few days. Some counties have a large number of cases (~1000) but a growth rate something like 7%, but most are in the range 10-30%.

- China built two hospitals with more than 1000 beds each, each within one week. What were your city / country doing when your hospitals were full?

As a Chinese student who study in Georgia, U.S. I have to tell you the truth.
I love my American friends, classmate and professors, they are the most wonderful people imaginable. However, in late January, when China had already warned the world for thousand times and cases in U.S started rising, most of them were doing the worst things imaginable. They genuinely believed that COVID-19 = seasonal flu, and they kept attending massive festivals or going to giant cities during long weekends, in fact some of them are probably of those Miami spring breakers who were exposed to YouTube.
China started to act in around Jan 25th, since then, it was showing the world of its methods: massive lock downs, face masks, quarantine, which later been followed by the wise countries like South Korea. In around Feb 7th, the new hospitals were finished and the first testing kit was coming out. Chinese were sacrificing everything to fight back the virus. Back in those days, I read the case number every hour and phoned my family every day, I was desperately wanting to go back home. In mid February, the curve started to flat out, despite one day there were suddenly more than 10k of new cases detected, and that was due to an introduction of more efficient testing standard.
Sadly, after these informations reached western countries, they were transferred into tools of slandering China after been reported by medias like CNN and politicians like Mr. Trump and Pompeo. I kept telling my friends to avoid massive social activities and even shared my face masks with them, but they would always reject politely, I think it is because deep down in mind, they think China is not trustworthy. I felt so sad that I eventually couldn't stop them from risking themselves or their family members.
Judging from China's case vs time table, I successfully predicted that the burst of cases in U.S would start in early March. Judging from what Americans were doing to stop Covid-19, I predicted that the outbreak will be much, much worse than China during its worst time, so I abandoned the upcoming quarter and was able to catch up the last few flights back to China. IMHO the plot makes case drop in last 7 days more visible, at the expense of making doubling time less visible. I'd think doubling time in an exponential growth is an important, if not the most important, characteristics. I made a colab notebook to show that the line basically is in the "main sequence" for doubling time = 0.5 days to 10 days.

https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1gt6hTVbmEdZ_e-Dduhpt6p-NHMhs8AJt#scrollTo=u6dvMcV_cEGq&uniqifier=1

However, for policy makers, 0.5 days and 10 days are probably very different.

A relative time series plot makes the doubling time very visible without losing the visual signal that new cases are decreasing, which reveals itself as flattening of the curve.

Just my 2 cents.

The idea of combining baking soda and lime juice draws on the basic principles of acidity and the pH scale.

Scientists use the pH scale to measure the acidity of a solution.

A solution can have a pH level between 0 and 14.

The lower the pH, the more acidic the solution, so:

pH levels below 7 indicate an acidic solution

pH levels above 7 indicate an alkaline, or base solution

Baking soda, also known as sodium bicarbonate, is a base.



This means that when people dissolve baking soda in water, it forms an alkaline solution.

For example, a 0.1 molar solution of baking soda has a pH of around 8.3.

Lime juice contains citric acid and ascorbic acid, has a pH of around 3.

Adding baking soda to lime juice will raise the pH to produce a more neutral solution.

There's another caveat missing: change in proportion to the population. If you flatten the curve, you still have exponential growth for a long time before you start dropping in new cases, but the exponential growth is at a smaller rate. It's hard to see that if you don't plot against time and if you don't consider the total population. A real success case, like Taiwan, is down at the bottom, growing slowly for a long time (since, say, first case, or first 10 or 100 cases). That's much better than the Chinese or Korean case, that took a much longer time to get there.

There is nothing wrong with plotting against time.
1. Take a difference (DIF) between the current total number of confirmed cases and the number of cases week before.
2. Take a sum (SUM) of the current total number of confirmed cases and the number of cases week before.
3. Divide DIF by SUM and plot the result (RAT) against time.
In the early stage RAT grows, then reaches maximum and stays flat for some period of time before it begins to go down (TD). TD corresponds to the moment of time after which propagation of the disease goes down approaching zero after while.

This is absolutely brilliant. It cuts through the noise and shows clearly what policies actually succeed against the virus. There are basically four kinds of response:
1. China (forced lock down, massive testing, isolation of positive patients). Near eradication - and I'm really surprised how many people find this shocking. It works. China may well be a totalitarian state, but its hardly surprising that if you keep people absolutely isolated, the virus must die out.
2. States that have attempted something less than a lock down but have implemented very high levels of testing, tracking and surveillance (Singapore, South Korea, Japan). In absolute (linear) terms these countries have done very well, comparatively. However, the presentation here shows that these countries have achieved an unstable equilibrium. Maybe South Korea is close to effective eradication (exception being imports) but if they are, this boils down to very early intervention. Good luck to them.
3. Coutnries that have essentially sailed blind into this such as Italy, but have been forced to implement emergency measures such as lockdown. What you see here is a trend first towards a slower exponential growth and then towards linear growth (fixed cases per day). This is not what I'd regard as control but its a platform upon which you can then implement mass testing and this will eventually see the virus trend to eradication. The UK is also in this group and its good that they are now talking about mass testing.
4. Countries like US (and potentially many others such as Brazil) with weak governance, fractured responses (divisions between levels of government) and worst of all, disinformation (yes, I'm looking at you, Fox News). The US may eventually end up in group 3 as something like mass lock down happens (whether it is forced by government or by the body count).


Bottom line. It doesn't matter what you think of China. The only things that work against this virus are physical control of people's movements, whether that's lockdowns or legally enforced social distancing, or both and mass testing and tracking. The more rigorous the action taken, the fewer cases/deaths and also, the less economic damage.
When cases are doubling every 2-3 days you are not beating anything.

While the graphs demonstrate admirably that all countries are on the same trajectory, I'm less confident in the 'success' stories. Three 'countries' (if we include the cruise ship Diamond Princess as a self-contained entity) have so far got off the main curve. One, Diamond Princess, would have naturally limited as it was a very small population effectively isolated from the outside world but with a much enhanced risk of transmission given the close quarters. China's figures, without wishing to minimise their efforts, have to be subject to some caution given their Government's initial denials and habitual manipulation of published statistics.


South Korea should be seen as a relatively reliable indicator; there is a democratic government, a well educated and connected populace and no prior record of systematic distortion of official statistics. However, the issue here is that the spread of the virus may have been atypical being largely focused around the rather secretive Shincheonji Church. The decline in growth seems to map to the church's change in stance. Initially it denied there was an issue and actively obstructed efforts to trace and isolate those with infections. The close proximity and large numbers of church members during worship made them a potent focus of infection. Once the church officially directed its members to cooperate with the medical authorities this seems to have had a significant impact on transmission rates.


Where does this leave us? The charts show that transmission follows a similar track wherever it occurs. If we can find more examples of countries where the growth in infections has reached a turning point then this would give more confidence in the charting. What these charts do not, in themselves, do is provide any way of predicting the point at which infection rates will begin to decline. At best they might indicate the relative merits of the measures undertaken in different countries.

This graphing system is good in theory, but the inaccuracies in data gathering make it almost academic. Iran, China, Russia and North Korea are some of the countries that are almost certainly submitting false data, whilst Japan and the UK aren't testing at a rate which provides accurate data. Unless a universal testing rate is implemented, and governments report accurately on their results, we are always going to be in the dark about whether we are "flattening the curve".


This also fails to account for social distancing/quarantine measures, population density, population figures, average age of populations, availability of hospital treatment (ventilators, staff, ICU beds etc.) and the staggered beginning of epidemics by nation. You could equate these factors to how growth evolves, but its impossible to know whether there is a correlation between these factors.

How to know if we’re ‘beating’ a virus: The world’s population doesn’t drop significantly with each passing day! No one’s ‘winning’ because there’s too many stupid people out there passing it around, making it harder for us normal minded people to just continue living our usual lives. This isn’t the 1300’s anymore, yet even with our advanced technological advances, such a simple rule as STAY HOME will likely make this worse than the Bubonic Plague before it finally does plateau/end - assuming anyone will even return to normalcy afterward. By then everyone will be driven so mad by fear mongering they won’t trust being close to anyone anymore.
These graphs have SEVERAL MAJOR problems and they’re all because hardly any hard facts are known about it. Here’s only a couple points:
1. It can live in the air and on certain surfaces for X time, but how much does weather affect it? When summer comes around for North America, it’s logical to think it will hang around even longer.
2. The 14 day quarantine doesn’t mean ANYTHING unless EVERYONE does it at the same time! Yes, eventually the ‘new cases’ stat will plateau and even descend, but if X people stay inside while Y morons don’t, then X people just wasted their time because they might get infected the moment they step back out of their house and the stats become even worse from the relapse!
3. The ‘6 foot minimum’ and ‘10 foot max gathering’ rules are completely stupid and useless because of how germs work. A cough/sneeze doesn’t stop at 6 feet - even covered SOME tiny portion will still be hanging around in the air! Then someone completely different might walk right through that cloud. As for the ‘10 person max’, it’s done far more harm than good to literally every aspect of human life. Just look at the unemployment rates because businesses had to shut down worldwide simply because they can’t trust Y moron to STAY HOME!
Even if/when the world ‘beats’ this, it will still take years for the public to recover - again assuming it ever does. For a perfect example here, look at how the US still hasn’t fully recovered from 9/11 because of all the stupid regulations that were put in place and are still around! The day after they finally remove the 6 foot and 10 people rule is when we’ll find out if it was beaten, or we end up facing a round 2.

And the real numbers may be even higher in nations that would be inclined to misreport their cases. And lets also not forget that it is easy to control a population when that population isn't Free... when they are living under an Authoritarian Regime, or even a Unitary State.

Qatar is a unitary absolute monarchy, which is an Authoritarian Dictatorship.

China is a unitary one-party socialist non-democratic republic... also an Authoritarian Dictatorship

Japan is a unitary state... so while it uses a parliamentary system... it is able to unilaterally make decisions for the entire nation. The same goes for South Korea.

But here is the important bit. Notice how every country that dropped off the average trajectory, eventually increased, again leading back to the normal path? You have to look at the very first drop offs, they rebounded... and the later drop offs were low when the graph stopped... but Qatar, China, Japan, South Korea, all had an uptick. First, it is important to know that they still had new cases... they only slowed the cases, and even then the cases were rising again. That is because you cannot stop the spread... you can only slow the inevitable.


Here's the important information...

It spreads like the Flu... which cannot be contained. And there is no vaccine. So the only way this is resolved, is through natural herd immunity. Which, unfortunately requires that people get sick, in order to develop natural immunities after they recover.

We cannot stop it. So we need to curb our emotional reactions, and stop getting angry at healthy people who don't isolate.

As to the "flatten the curve" philosophy... it is misguided, and needs to be more nuanced.

Flattening the curve is meant to prevent overloading hospitals all at once, and spread out the cases so that they can be handled at a better pace. But this does not require every demographic to isolate.

The only people that should be isolating is the elderly, the immunocompromised, people that aren't healthy, and healthy people that must be in frequent contact with the aforementioned individuals. These are the cases that would end up needing hospitalization... so these are the cases that the curve needs to be flattened for.

Healthy people that don't have frequent contact with at risk individuals... should not be isolating... because they will be most effective when they are immune... which means they must get sick and recover. And this needs to happen as quickly as possible. Instructing those people to isolate only slows the inevitable, without having a significant impact on flattening the curve of hospitalization cases. And what little they do impact the curve... it is worth the risk in order to get herd immunity sooner. It will also decrease the negative impact on economies that are already going to be severely impacted.

And for those that feel there are too many people, in that scenario, that aren't isolating. Think about the exceptions I mentioned... that is a huge portion of the population anyway. Anyone that is elderly, anyone that is unhealthy, anyone that is obese, anyone that is immunocompromised, anyone that cares for those people, anyone in the medical fields, doctors nurses, hospital workers, clinic workers, nursing home workers... plenty of people should isolate.

But the healthy that don't happen to fall under those categories... should keep calm, and carry on... as the Brits say.

Two very important things to note:

- Some countries are notoriously bad for covering up or not reporting cases properly, China, Russia, and to a lesser extent the US/Sweden aren't super great sources, there's multiple reports of people deliberately not being tested and likely done so they don't have to increase the confirmed tally. Additionally it's well known that China and Russia do not like admitting to mistakes or reporting accurately to skew the perception of their countries and their responses, it's likely that both have much much higher infected individuals than is being reported.

- Coronavirus isn't going to 'go away', it's not like cases will reach 0 and then suddenly the virus is gone forever never to rear it's ugly head again, at best the rampant spread will be curtailed by immunity and vaccines should they be produced. But it will always be important to remember the lessons learned from it, namely that we need to be more aware of those that are compromised and improve how we respond to highly infectious diseases, without change to how we do things the next case like this will have the same disastrous spread with potentially much greater impact. Yes the wildfire will calm down, yes the amount of infected individuals will slow and decline, but the people most at risk of dying from the infection are still there and all it takes is sloppy medical care and a lack of personal responsibility for them to be in just as much danger as they are right now.

First, anyone who believes China has only had 3295 deaths from Covid-19 is truly a sucker. You don’t quarantine nearly 12 Million people if only 27 people had died by Dec 31.

Based on the number of reported cremations, a better estimate for Chinese deaths due to Covid-19 tops 50,000. This indicates an infection rate of 500,000 minimum, and suggests Dec 31 saw 270 deaths, not 27.

Third, the USA death rate is 1/10th of Italy’s, and certainly less than China’s. The infection rate is skewed, because the USA invented superior tests, and has run 10x the number of tests run by China. Furthermore, USA testing has proved the spread of the virus cannot and was not stopped by quarantine.

Finally, if anyone thinks China has beaten this virus, then they need to think again. Do you really expect us to believe a nation of over 1 Billion was able to stop the spread to other jurisdictions outside of Wuhan? Bunk.

China is likely to endure over 500,000,000 infections, and over 5,000,000 deaths before Covid-19 has run its course. We now know there’s no need for young folks to die from it. However, 99% of deaths are in the population 55 and over, and nearly half of China’s population was in this bracket. They were threatening to break the Chinese pension system before the outbreak.

If I was prone to conspiracy theory, then I’d make the conjecture that the Chinese government invented this virus in a lab aimed at creating a means of killing off the elderly to keep them from bankrupting the Chinese form of Social Security. In biology there is a prevailing theory of how populations propagate. Its usually expressed as something called a K-line. It give some broad avenues of what a population can do, how fast it can do it, and how that will affect the stability of that population going forward. The idea, in a nutshell, is that exponential growth of a population in a biome can only be sustained for so long. Resources become depleted. How quickly those resources replenish helps determine where the population falls on the k-line. If the relationship is stable, some of the population may die but the biome achieves some level of homeostatic equilibrium and the populations that rely on each other will rise and fall in, roughly, sine waves. The other broad choice is collapse of the population, which in this case would be rapidly infecting everyone, leaving the virus no new prey unless it rapidly mutates. The problem is that the k-line is about how populations of organisms interact, and in this case we are the prey being depleted. Both populations can be crashed by overconsumption, first of the prey itself and then everything else down the chain as panic spreads and holes appear in, presumably, once stable biomes.

At 1:31 they flash the text "*Hertzsprung-Russell, anyone?".

If anyone is curious, Hertzsprung-Russell diagrams, or HRDs, originated from scatter plots comparing a star's luminosity to its temperature. These scatter plots all have a main sequence, which I suppose in context would be the countries that have not dropped from the logarithmic curve or countries that do not appear to have the disease under control yet. The video does not mention HRDs by name, I'm assuming because we're not talking about stars, but its the exact same concept.

These HRDs also do not plot against time to make it easier to see an overall effect (same as discussed in the video). This feature, in many cases such as with Covid-19, makes it MUCH easier to analyze data and predict future outcomes. If you want to simulate a time dimension, imagine the lines drawing themselves as countries' plotted curves are added to day by day (he explains how this is shown through animation).

That's a basic overview from what I've gathered, but if you are more curious check the Wikipedia page:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hertzsprung-Russell_diagram

And Don't forget the link in the description to see the updated graph yourself!

There's a couple of things you missed that are actually very important.
While you pointed out that number of cases is not number of infected people, you overlooked that the cases counted are not necessarily comparable, either. A country that tests very aggressively will have a lot of confirmed cases, but a lot of these cases will be mild ones - mildly symptomatic or even asymptomatic. Detecting those is actually good, because it allows to isolate these people and prevent them from infecting others - so despite the fact that case numbers will look high, control over the spread is much better. On the other hand, a country which is already on the verge of breakdown or in full chaos will likely only test what's ending up at the hospital anyway. So the former may even count more cases than the latter, but the percentage of infections being tracked is higher and the bulk of the cases being found is much milder.

Another point: we're on the verge of getting new tests that will simplify testing - consequently, the number of confirmed cases is likely to explode. Case numbers post quick-test will not be comparable with case numbers pre-quick test.


Similarly, a country in which the situation relaxes may find the resources to do more out of hospital testing and see case numbers rise again more quickly.


So simply comparing number of cases largely tracks an artifact of test availability that says precious little as to how bad the situation is. I think the number of deaths is a more solid parameter, though even that has problems, since not every country is doing postmortem diagnosis and thus, people dying of previously undiagnosed COVID-19 don't necessarily get counted.

Corona viruses aren't like the measles or mumps...it is not a one and done virus...there are at lease 3 coronaviruses that cause the common cold...and you can catch a cold a hundred times over. So a straight-line assessment of where we are going with this particular virus isn't really possible...if it like other coronaviruses act in such a way as to make it difficult or impossible for our bodies to actually develop immunity...most likely scenario is that we develop partial immunity...how effective that becomes remains to be seen. Of course this takes into account TIME...and that is what concerns us...how LONG will this last...really hard to say as this virus in NOT going away, just as the common cold hasn't gone away. I'm hopeful that we (the human race) develops some strong anti-bodies that combat this virus effectively, but to do that the infection will need to run its course...kind of a natural outcome thing...we adapt or we die...we have been awful good at adapting and I see no reason to believe this will prove otherwise. Life finds a way...just as the coronavirus (a living thing) found a way to adapt (change) and survive in other hosts (us). Regardless, keep up the good work...facts over fear.

My question is, would it be beneficial to see a graph that shows the % of population of a country infected (or newly infected) rather than the total number of infected or total new infection rate.  My thinking is, as infections spread, less population has the chance to be infected, so if you see a huge decline in new infection rates, it could just mean that most people in a country are infected so there is less ability for the infection to find new hosts.    For example, if country A has one hundred thousand people and country B has 300 million people, and we see a rapid growth of an infection, to the point where both countries have eighty thousand people infected, but then the numbers start to drop off for country A, but keep going for country B, it doesn't necessarily mean that country A has found some solution to the problem and is doing a better job than Country B at containing the spread, it might just mean, the remaining twenty thousand people are staying indoors and avoiding getting infected...where as Country B has so many more people to chance getting infected, but they are doing a better job as a percentage of their population at keeping it in check.

This is not a rigorous test by any means, but an estimation. If you want a better idea of the actual number of cases, better data would be ideal, but there is another way.

Assuming a roughly homogenous population in any given region, here is one way to get an estimate for how many cases there might be.

Let t be the proportion of the population in a region. That has been tested. The variable t includes positive and negative results.

Let P be the total population. Let t(i) be the proportion of the tested population. The value of t(i)=confirmed cases/t. From here take t(i)*P to get the the approximate number of cases.

The reason for this is that since the population is roughly homogenous, the proportion of any two subsets of the poulation that are infected should be approximately the same value.

Say for instance that P=100, t=20, and t(i)=0.35, then extrapolating to the entire population P*t(i) is about 35 people who likely have the illness. So my method boils down to equivalent fractions.

It is definitely not a perfect method, but it is just an estimate. Any ideas on how to make a better estimate? I would like feedback. Maybe I should incorporate something more technical involving calculus or something.

Really interesting, but in some cases the caveats really overwhelm the advantages of this graph. Think of German v Italy, both situated side by side on your graph, with virtually the same trajectory. But Germany has limited the new infections to between 4.000 and 6.000 new cases every day for the last 6 or 7 days now, despite the number of overall cases rising from 15.000 to 50.000in the same time, so their ratio should already be plummeting (caveat: delayed effect on the graph); also, Germany only has had 325 deaths so far, wheres Italy had 8.200 despite only having twice as many overall confirmed cases (caveat: only cases tracked, not mortality); also, the real infection numbers in Italy are presumably much higher, since Germany has tested more and earlier than any other EU country (caveat: only confirmed cases counted, without regard to testing capability). So all these caveats make two countries, that are on vastly different trajectories right now (to the extend that Germany actually takes on corona virus cases from Italy) look exactly the same.
I think these graphs might be more useful if both axes were normalized against the populations of each country.

Further investigation of the "new cases vs cumulative cases" graph indicates that the slope of the graph [log (# of new cases)/log(# of cum. cases] is about 0.81. Then the expected number of new cases at a given number of cumulative cases is (# of cum. cases)^0.81.  Allowing a safety margin of 3%, the fall of number of new cases below the threshold  can be considered as passing the turning point.  For example, Italy has the cumulative number of 86498 cases today, the threshold is at (86498)^(0.81*0.97)=7568 cases.  As the number of new cases today is 5909 cases which is below the threshold, I can say that Italy has passed the turning point and would be improved day after day.  This kind of test is very easy to do and can also be used to compare the relative situations between countries or between regions.

For the very reason that I find the graphs very interesting, I would suggest to include the possibility of selecting the active cases for the X axis, if anyone can forward this suggestion to Aatish.
The reason is this, using the total cases is effective in showing the trend and identifying the "main sequence" (yep, totally stolen from astrophysics, here indicates the unmitigated spread for the "social dynamics" of epidemics-unaware societies, which so far appear to be very similar around the world) only for the first cluster of infection.
If effective measures are taken and the curve drops from the main sequence, it becomes difficult to tell if and when a new unmitigated spread starts.
For instance I can't tell if Japan is still in control, as it was at the start of its curve, or it is now "losing control" (getting into a "community sustained" spread?) and the curve is converging to the main sequence. If would be even more difficult to identify for China and S.Korea at this point, but it is a crucial information (e.g. in the moment one country is relaxing restrictive measures: are we keeping in control of the epidemic or are we losing control again? This is the critical question during the transition from generalized measures to focused ones.).
The difficulty stems from the fact that the "total" counter doesn't reset, it still counts the closed cases. This is an historical memory that is not really relevant to assess the state of the situation.
The possibility of checking the active cases (as another option for the X axis) probably would render the curves more sensitive to "restarts" after the first cluster.
Thanks in advance.
Best regards.

Is the epidemic out of control or not. After thinking about it for a great deal of time I realised there is a simple method of determining this. The critical question is, do we know where all the infected cases are or not. If we do not knw where all the infections are then the epidemic is out of control, if we do know where all the infections are then its under control.

The first issue I had was the numbers of those infected varied so much as to be meaningless. It depends on testing regime, more testing results in more infections for example. The other is in many countries people are infected but not reporting, in china you would only present if you were in very poor health, otherwise you would stay at home. In summary, the numbers inflected metric is too unreliable to be useful.

The one metric we do have which has a very high accuracy, although not 100%, is deaths. The next step is converting this into infections. Most people who studied and currently work in the field of disease control estimate the probably mortality rate is 1%, based on current data. This may not be correct and it may go up and down depending on a range of factors such as average age of the population and health system, but is a useful start point. Thus if we multiply the number of people who have died by 100 we will probably have an idea of the number of symptomatic inflections. If this value varies from the official infection rate a lot this could tell us one of three things. To account for any variability i use an error factor of +/-25%,

If the number of people who have died multiplied by 100 is greater than the official infection rate, it reasonable to assume there are a lot of unknown infections and as a result its out of control and needs a severe response. (125% or greater)

If the number of people who have died multiplied by 100 is roughly equal to the official infection rate, its reasonable to assume most of the infections are known and the epidemic is controllable, but still needs some response. (75% to 125%)

If the number of people who have died multiplied by 100 is less than the official infection rate, it’s reasonable to assume most of the infections are known and the testing is showing a large number of asymptomatic infections. This also means its being controlled. (less than 75%)

Once controlled then targeted responses to deal with specific clusters can be implemented. The curve should start flattening in this case, but remember than there is latency in any disease, so even if you control it on day one, it could be day 14 before the curve starts flattening. I use this methodology with the numbers on worldometer to determine what is happening and I think its giving me a reasonable view.

You give in to the same false impression of the media that gives Trump and others the same fuel to bash the news. The news, when done right, is not there to tell people what to think. It's simply there to present the facts available so that the reader can make up their mind about their own choices. It's why reporters will quote people from both sides of a piece, even if one side can be considered by the majority to be a nut job. Quoting them shows that there at least does exist an alternative side of things.

The news is supposed to be like science. It doesn't care what you think or feel, it just states the facts so you can figure out how you want to process the information. There's often a story connected to it mostly because it's a proven thing that it is the kind of thing to grab attention so you actually receive the important information. And yes, there's an entire formula and psychology to reporting.

Ever notice how the first paragraph of a story tends to be small, and the second tends to be larger and often repeats what the first said? That's because most people skimming a paper or news site only read the first paragraph before deciding if they want to continue. It's called the lead. It's basically the short pitch to get you to read the rest. The next paragraph is the actual start of the news piece and offers more context to what's said in the lead.

I'm meandering, but my point is here, that right now, we don't have the data (largely due to the lack of wide testing), so instead of reporting on maybes and what ifs, right now they're focused on what is. It's why you've seen stories about china starting to get control, because there's data to support that. Until there's verifiable sources that show we are getting better in north america, you're not likely going to see it, because until then, its not fact so its not news.

As a back of the envelope clue to when the shoulder will happen, I've been plotting the ratio of total cases between successive days. In exponential growth this number should be constant, = e^(ln(2)/T), where T is doubling time. With Corona this number has been typically 1.3 or so, then sliding off to 1.1 as the shoulder begins. Canada and many other countries have seen this already, the US, not.... Of course behavioral change, testing criteria, and even diagnosis (?China) will change results dramatically.

I wish, that when data is presented for various segments of the population (whether by age, location, whatever), the data were presented as a proportion of the total number of people in their segment.
In this particular case, rather than showing number of cases and number of new cases segmented by country, I would like to see (number of cases/population) and (number of new cases/population). This would not change the overall shape of the graph, which is a bunch of lines of slope 1, but would move the points along that slope-1 line. The distance moved would depend on the population.
The point of doing this is that it avoids giving the impression that the disease is worse in a larger country or better in a smaller one.

The problem with tracking the disease progress by using the number of case is testing bias. What do I mean by that. Well the easiest way to not find new cases is not to test and testing more will find more (if we did't think there were lost more untested infected people out there, why are are we doing social distancing). Sp how can you account for that bias? I can see two ways:
1) Count cases based on estimated symptom onset data rather than testing date then look at the shape / slope of the curve. This is what US CDC is doing. See https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/cases-in-us.html. Note: You have to wait a couple of weeks before this data is indicative (the viral gestation + reporting delay period). hold on, if it's a graph of total reported cases t vs new reported cases D, then in case of exponential growth it has to be linear in linear scale :
D = a*t
and in log scale it has to be a 45 degrees line above or below zero:
log D = log a + log t

this means that the angle of all those lines is always 45 degrees regardless of how quickly the virus spreads

If you want a better way to generate basic "when does this end" predictions, you should plot a quadratic regression to your plot of y' vs y. Because we expect the growth to be fairly logistic this plot will actually be quadratic and not linear. This allows us to fit a quadratic regression to the data of the form (ax^2 +bx +c) from which we can get values and errors for a and b. We can then uses the values to find the peak of this quadratic (-b/2a) which corresponds to the number of cases when we are halfway to the peak of the disease. By properly propagating the error in the values of a and b, we then get a new interval for the approximate number of cases which we expect to see at the peak of the disease (lets call this value k for now). Then an exponential regression can be fit to the raw case data of the form (ce^(dx)) so that values and standard errors for c and d can be found. We can then solve for x as a function of c,d and k and we see that x = (2/d)ln(k/2c). Finally, propagating the error once again we're left with an interval representing the day we'll most likely hit the carrying capacity of the disease.


Doing this with the data available back in March 15th it was predicted that the peak would occur somewhere between April 17th and April 26th. But now with the current data this interval has shifted to May 5 - May 10th as of the currently available data today (these are just the numbers for the US btw, but using data from another country of interest or the global population can easily let you make the same predictions for these other populations).

@minutephysics 3:15 The exponential growth on a log-log graph would look exponential, not linear. It would look linear on a linear-log graph. The new cases per day is actually a derivative of the total cases, so it would be linear for a polynomial function, but would still be exponential for an exponential function. So, even if you plot new cases on a log-log scale, you won't get a straight line if the growth is exponential. If you get a straight line on a log-log scale, it means the growth is polynomial.

There is an important point i would like to make about the reliability of the data. As you said, looking at the number of infected is not very reliable, as most countries aren't testing enough people, and the amount of testing varies greatly. However, one set of the data is highly reliable, and that is the deaths from COVID-19, as this is much easier to test/verify.
So, if you in your graph replaced the new cases vs existing cases with new deaths vs previous deaths, you should get way more accurate results.


Likewise, you could use the death-numbers to more accurately calculate the real infection numbers, than looking at the reported numbers.

Some estimates I have heard:
- 40-70% of us will catch the virus sometime in the next few weeks or months depending on how flat the curve stays in your country.
- 20% of cases will have significant symptoms
- up to 15% will require a hospital visit and 3-10% will require ICU.
- even in ICU 1-3% will still die, and that number goes up as high as 8% if the hospital's are overrun and ICU services are not available.
- ICU beds are also not available for other non COVID patients so more of them will die too but not make it into the statistics.
- If another disaster happens anywhere in the world while hospital's are already full, there will be no help for those people.

So let's say you know 500 people, friends, family and work contacts
, those you have had personal contact with in the last year.
If things are better than average: 200 of them will get COVID
30 will visit the hospital
15 will visit the ICU
2 will die - yes on the good side you may still personally know 2 people who die from this.

If things go poorly:
350 of them will get it
53 of then will visit the hospital
35 of them will visit the ICU
28 of them will die.
So you could personally know 28 people who die from COVID-19 and maybe others who did not get access to hospital care for other conditions.

Don't think this could happen to your friends, ask someone in Italy if it is possible.

It was indirectly alluded to a couple times, but it’s worth noting more directly. The inaccuracy of case numbers goes beyond just the inability to account for them all.

Many countries have likely fudged the numbers for PR reasons, but China is uniquely unreliable. The culture of the CCP incentivizes coverups and inaccurate reporting, so they could be wildly off and not even know it.

They are also known to deliberately lie to the world, though. They specifically suppressed knowledge of the virus, priming it to catch the rest of the planet off guard so they aren’t above it.

That said, it’s still likely that their methods have had at least some significant success, so it may only make the global data sets slightly less accurate.

Of course, it’s also worth mentioning that China’s tactics have regularly traipsed into the uniquely and unnecessarily draconian. We need to work together but it would be a mistake to ignore how all this started in the first place.

While it's an interesting way to detect when countries have stopped growing exponentially, I fear it's a bad choice if your point is to show that "we're all on the same trajectory just shifted in time". Sure all the trajectories seem to roughly fall on the same line (until they drop out) but almost any exponential will follow that line. In fact you could have predicted up front that all trajectories will have a slope of 1. At most the trajectories will be shifted horizontally a little, which will be hard to see if your y axis needs to span 4 orders of magnitude, and in this case small differences (i.e. a 20% vs a 25% increase per day) have huge consequences.

If you just want to show the growth is exponential until it isn't then it's a good graph, but if you want to compare the exponential growth between countries then it would be better to estimate the base of the exponential directly. By, for instance, plotting the relative increase (i.e. new cases per week divided by total cases) against either time or the total number of infections.

The problem is that there is not enough data. Cases in the US are increasing exponentially largely because the number of tests being done is increasing exponentially.

Also, if growth is "stopped", the remainder of the population is still uninfected, meaning as soon as life goes back to normal it starts up again. Take China for example. If their numbers are to believed, only 50 out of every million people have been infected, meaning that the population there is still just as vulnerable as it was during the growth phase. Compare that against smaller European countries that have more extensive testing available due to their small populations, such as Iceland. There you see as much as 2000 out of every million infected. In those countries exponential growth is not really possible for much longer because the virus is running out of new people to infect.

Where do other countries with larger populations sit? Most likely European countries are similar to Iceland, they just dont have as much testing going on. In places like Italy which are further along the true infection rate likely has alllready plateaued out, even though increasing testing numbers might make it seem like it is "growing".

For example, South Korea's the infection rate appears to be slowing down because the government is testing fewer people per day (due to politics). The data that is most accurate and most telling is the death rate. If you infer the number of new cases based on the death count, it is clear that the rate of infection in Korea is not slowing down. In the US, if you infer the new case count based on the death rate, it is just beginning to accelerate.

Excellent work ... I just want to make an addition to the warnings of the graphs limitations. It treats each country uniformly, only the numbers. The reason why this and every major viral epidemic we have had over the last few decades comes from China, and why China's and South Korea's actions have the appearance or reality of containment or "bending the curve" is population distribution and genetic homogeneity.

Population distribution, its really hard for Americans or European who have never been to Asia to fathom how massively huge the population is in general or how big these cities really are in juxtaposition. In a recent engagement where I was making arguments why Universal Healthcare isn't realistic in the US, people where in utter disbelief when I stated the city Tokyo is about equal in population to the entire state of California ... it's a fact, but these college students couldn't comprehend it. Due to economies of scale and resource utilization, the cost to provide healthcare person at the same quality is 5 times cheaper in one versus the other.

On that note, even though China is roughly the same size as the continental US, about 1.2 of their 1.3 billion people live in an area on the coast about the size of California. The US and the 330 mil people that live here are spread out and the Urban/Rural ratio is about 50/50 depending the measurement parameters.

The genetic homogeneity thing is a big thing epidemiology, compare "British" India versus China, about equal in population. Why don't we have a lot of pandemics originating there? Bigger spread of the population and their dietary difference (not a lot of cattle ranches and pig farms over there) are huge, but there is much more genetic diversity from Kashmir to Bangladesh to Sri Lanka. In that crucial first phase a virus has to figure out how to make "universal key" to enter the cells to spread. Like if everyone had their front door locks or encryption software made by the same company. Once you figure out one, you can get into the rest fairly easy.

Great video, lots of good points.  This stuff is kind of important to grasp in normal times, but in times of crisis and panic, having people understand what the data says and what that means is critical.  There is another thing that needs to keep being highlighted, and that is the time delay between action and consequences.  Because the virus takes a few days to a couple weeks to show symptoms, and very few people get tested before they have clear symptoms, good practices (social distancing, closed public areas, etc) will take at least a week to slow increases in cases, because "new cases" were probably infected before the practices were put in place, conversely, poor practices, like large gatherings or relaxing of social distancing will take weeks to cause the growth rate to speed up again.
