Few things:


1) there's not enough testing to go around, so we're not seeing the whole picture. Basically we're looking at the big picture through a keyhole, and the amount of testing we can do is that keyhole. The more testing we can do, the wider the keyhole. The testing being done is only on folks that think they have something and present themselves for testing. There could be folks that have it silently wandering around spreading it, b/c they don't show symptoms. And, when they get symptoms, it's mild. So, they think the just have allergies or a cold or something. The good thing is the worry about covid is prompting more folks to show up for testing. So, you get to see if someone does just have a mild sniffle or if they have covid. The bad thing is we have folks rushing to get tested if they cough once. This is where healthcare professionals have to make the assessment on who gets the test.


2) since covid has 1-14 day incubation period, 5 on avg, by the time we see the curve, it's already had a week to build up in a population via transmission. This is why places that take proactive measures to self-quarantine a week or two before they get hit are fairing better then places that wait to do something when they first notice it. (By the time you notice the start of the curve, it's already on you big-time... this is what happened to NYC, China, etc). People in areas going "I don't know what the big deal is, nothing is goign on here".. yes, because you took proactive measures. That's the whole point of proactive measures.


3) the measure of an illness is also how badly it impacts a person. Covid seems to impact folks in different ways; majority get mild symptons, some get severe symptions, some lead to death. But, this leads some folks to a false sense of security. It's like looking on tech forums and someone goes "well, I haven't had that issue with my PC", but they draw a broad generalization based on their limited example and just assume nobody else will have a problem. This is dangerous thinking. Even if people are not having bad issues, they can still risk passing it on to others that can.


4) the infection rate for covid is about 2x that of flu.. and infecetion rate is exponential. So, you have pow(infection rate, degrees of separation). Degrees of Separation is how many jumps the virus had made.. (Think of it like the 6 Degrees of Kevin Bacon.. how many jumps do you need to make to get from one person to Kevin Bacon.. and most people can tie back to Kevin Bacon in 6 jumps... Person A knows person B knows person C.. etc.. until someone knows Kevin Bacon). The Covid has a rate of 3. So, 1 person can give it to 3, those 3 give it to 3 more each (9), etc, etc. Prof Hugh Montgomery had a vid comparing flu to covid. Flue has 1.3 or 1.4 ... if it makes 10 jumps (10 degrees of separation) 1.3 to power of 10 is like 14, and 1.4 to power of 10 is like 28. 3 (covid's infection rate) to power of 10 is 59,000 people infected. HOW they respond to the infection is the biggest concern.. again, might hit some people miniroly, while others end up in ER on respirators.


5) the infection curve is tempered with our healthcare capacity curve. The CDC has a flat-dashed-line on their "flatten the curve" chart. Every location has a finite amount of healthcare. But, in many places, it's operating close to capacity already. Now we're tossing a new healthcare issue on top of it, and it can quickly max out the healthcare system. Healthcare workers can operate overtime, but they can't do that indefinitely. So, over time, the healthcare system degrades in effectiveness. People become exhausted to the point of not being able to work. Their immune system gets whacked from stress, so they get sick or possibly even catch the virus themselves. They become overhwlemed and frustrated and decide to quit. As our healthcare system is being overwhelemed, it doesn't remain operating at a constant max capacity; it's degrading over time.. that's why you want to get this infection curve under control ASAP. Because, a weakened healthcare system is like a weakened immune system.. it leaves you vulnerable for a secondary problem. And, history has shown that major outbreaks often hit in waves. We're dealing with 1st wave. If our healthcaer system is over-taxed and broken after it, then if we get hit with a 2nd wave (or another issue, like smallpox or what-not shows up).. we're in seriuos trouble.


6) on a long-term scale.. the decisions on how to deal with this, and how many people we think are an "acceptable loss" to die to it...People are not machines. We don't just pull them out of the server racks, order new ones, and replace them a week later, fully imaged with software and up-n-running like nothing was happening. Humans take YEARS to grow, educate and invest in. In some places, birth rates were already low (amount of new borns replacing amount of people dying). Now lets add on amount of people dying from this. That is an extra burden of population we have to replace. And we can't replace it over night. The financial loss in the people that die isn't as drastic as the TIME loss in them. An 18yo that dies.. that's 18 YEARS of time spent raising and educating them to "boot the up" to almost become a productive member of society. A 40-seomthing that dies.. that's 40 YEARS of time investment we just lost. Now do the math for every person that dies and determine how many years. I'm an analyst by trade. I crunched some numbers. The financial loss from the people dying is a drop in the bucket, but the time lost in growing and developing them into productive citizens is a MAJOR impact. Companies wanting to just open their doors and have folks working more are bieng short-sighted. We could have a pandemic drastically killing off labor forces, and then (to their greedy asses), it creates a labor deficit, which means workers have the power to demand higher wages, because there's less work force. (Supply and demand). Companies wanting to keep operating or operate ASAP are wanting to make money now while making it harder for themselves in the future. (That's from a purely business perspective.. so it boggles my mind that teh businsses haven't thought of this).


7) An issue we're seeing is .. places that get it under control aren't giving it enough time to snuff out. China, for instance. They got it under control in Wuhan, then they started opening up travel again. Once you have the lid back on Pandora's Box, you don't open the damn thing again. You give it time for the fire to snuff out. That's like two weeks or so. Too many countries are getting it under control, and acting like that means they've snuffed it out. So, we're going to see a 2nd wave of this stuff running around sooner or later.


8) The goal with getting it "under control" isn't to make everyone immune. It's so that we can let folks get infected in a controlled fashion that the healthcare industry can deal with the problems within capacity without being overwhelmed, and we give sick folks time to recover and become "human shields" of Herd Immunity. A person that recovers is no longer infectious themselves, but, they could still carry the virus on their hands or clothes if they're still not practicing proper hygeine. (IE: so them coughing on you won't make you sick, but if they interacted with people still contagious, and didn't was their hands before hsaking your hand, they could still pass it on). As we get more and more folks recovering, they act like shields that help "fence off" certain parts of society, which can help prevent others from getting sick. But, as we've seen, this virus is a silent ninja that spreads around and hits before folks even realize it. But, as more people recover, they can't get it again, which helps slow the virus spreading if they are still cautious and use proper sanitation and hygeine.



9) Some of us old farts have lived through some crazy shit (80's market crashes, 9/11, H1N1 / SARS).. this thing is nothing.. NOTHING like what we've seen in the past. This is a once-in-a-lifetime healthcare event that needs to be taken seriously. The biggest part that's pissing me off is that proactive measures can easily help temper how badly this thing hits, but we're seeing so many countries not take it seriuosly until it's on their doorstep. Filling sand bags when teh hurricane is already on your doorstep.. it's too late. The other part is seeing countries think the threat has past moments after they get it under control. They are in the eye of a hurricane. They need to stay hunkered down and take things seriously so the 2nd wave doesn't hurt them as bad. There is just so much short-sightedness going on via people in power. And, gov'ts keep telling folks to "shelter in place", but don't give them a means to. People here in the states dont' qualify for unemployment if they voluntarily quit their job. Companies know this, so they stay open and workers are forced to come into potentially hazerdous work environments as their only means of support. IF they had an alternate means, like getting unemployment for a month of two if they voluntarilty quit their job, then they could have an option to stay home and big business wouldn't be dictating how many bodies we throw on the fire from the top-down (while people in power are shetering in their mansions). This is really pulled the curtain back on the social divides in countries.

I'd argue that one of the reasons you get such a linear graph with basically all countries matching each other is that this representation cancels out the detection bias. Countries with very little testing end up with fewer total case numbers but fewer new cases at the same time. In reality, it is still possible that the gradient of this graph is dramatically different for every country. A decent indicator is the death rate. Death rarely goes undetected so most COVID-19 related deaths will be recorded. Countries with a very high death rate are more likely to simply have performed way too few tests, since the death rate should not vary by orders of magnitude unless a health care system gets completely overwhelmed.

A second spike in cases for any country that gets off the exponential growth curve (or line) through containment measures (like lock-downs) is very much likely, when they open their borders for international travel.
But, I don't think the plot shown here will work in that case. The reason for this is the following:
Here, what is shown on the x-axis is the "total number of CONFIRMED cases" - this is not going to change when the second spike begins. A better representation of reality is to plot the "total number of ACTIVE cases" vs new cases. The time-point will move back and along the same line with each separate spikes as there will be a drop in total number of active cases between spikes.

Logarithm of the exponentially growing value is sufficient when plotting against time. The thing about uncontained exponential case is that it's actually hard to hide. Sure, a country can suppress the numbers by an order of magnitude (or two) through lack of testing or other means, but that's just a few days of growth on the exponential scale.

Just think about that for a minute. If the growth is actually not contained, the number of cases will soon overwhelm the medical system and then you get 5-10% fatality rate and not the 1% that you see. Even at 5%, that's so many bodies in such a short period of time that you'll need serious infrastructure to even get rid of them without a pileup on the streets. You can't hide that in this day and age, firewalls be damned.

Excellent presentation. But...The main problem with this is GIGO. The CDC does not know how many cases there are or how many new cases are added. The CDC tells you in the footnotes that the numbers for infections and deaths, even going back several years for regular flu, are estimates. New cases are only recognized when recorded by the CDC. Since these are the 2 data-points of the graph, and neither one has any accuracy, the graph is is highly misleading, at best. Garbage In = Garbage Out, aka GIGO.

From CDC web site: "* Data include both confirmed and presumptive positive cases of COVID-19 reported to CDC or tested at CDC since January 21, 2020...."

What is a "Presumptive" case? A clue is also on the CDC web site footnotes: "†Self-reported by health department characterizing the level of community transmission in their jurisdiction as: “Yes, widespread” (defined as: widespread community transmission across several geographical areas); “Yes, defined area(s)” (defined as: distinct clusters of cases in a, or a few, defined geographical area(s)); “Undetermined” (defined as: 1 or more cases but not classified as “Yes” to community transmission)...."

GIGO!
